t: Proverbs 26
Similitudes, Instructions
Like*pn snow in summer and like rain in harvest, So*ln honor is not fitting for a fool.
Like*ln a sparrow in its*i flitting, like a swallow in its*i flying, So*ln a curse without cause does not alight.
A*ln whip is for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, And*ln a rod for the back of fools.
Do*ln not answer a fool according to his folly, Or*ln you will also be like him.
Answer*ln a fool as his folly deserves,*i That*ln he not be wise in his own eyes.
He*ln cuts off his*i own*i feet and*i drinks violence Who*ln sends a message by the hand of a fool.
Like*iln the legs which*i are useless to the lame, So*ln is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like*ln one who binds a stone in a sling, So*ln is he who gives honor to a fool.
Like*iln a thorn which*i falls into the hand of a drunkard, So*ln is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
Like*iln an archer who wounds everyone, So*ln is he who hires a fool or who hires those who pass by.
Like*ln a dog that returns to its vomit Is*ln a fool who repeats his folly.
Do*ln you see a man wise in his own eyes? There*ln is more hope for a fool than for him.
The*ln sluggard says, “There is a lion in the road! A*ln lion is in the open square!”
As*iln the door turns on its hinges, So*ln does*i the sluggard on his bed.
The*ln sluggard buries his hand in the dish; He*ln is weary of bringing it to his mouth again.
The*ln sluggard is wiser in his own eyes Than*ln seven men who can give a discreet answer.
Like*iln one who takes a dog by the ears Is*ln he who passes by and*i meddles with strife not belonging to him.
Like*ln a madman who throws Firebrands,*ln arrows and death,
So*ln is the man who deceives his neighbor, And*ln says, “Was I not joking?”
For*ln lack of wood the fire goes out, And*ln where there is no whisperer, contention quiets down.
Like*iln charcoal to hot embers and wood to fire, So*ln is a contentious man to kindle strife.
The*ln words of a whisperer are like dainty morsels, And*ln they go down into the innermost parts of the body.
Like*iln an earthen vessel overlaid with silver dross Are*ln burning lips and a wicked heart.
He*ln who hates disguises it*i with his lips, But*ln he lays up deceit in his heart.
When*ln he speaks graciously, do not believe him, For*ln there are seven abominations in his heart.
Though*iln his*i hatred covers itself with guile, His*ln wickedness will be revealed before the assembly.
He*ln who digs a pit will fall into it, And*ln he who rolls a stone, it will come back on him.
A*ln lying tongue hates those it crushes, And*ln a flattering mouth works ruin.
